reviewText: If seeing naked women in funny situations is what you're looking for, you're better off seeing Playboy's Really Naked Truth or one of the Candid Candid Camera series.

It had been almost 30 years since I saw this in the theater and looked forward to the VHS version. I was somewhat disappointed because it contains too much "discussion" at the expense of some of the great original footage not included on the VHS release.

This movie is a dated but the movie also shows a glimpse into the minds of the people of the era. Of particular interest in this movie where the interviews done with people who screened the movies before it was released.

This was pretty funny and left me kind of nostalgic.  I remember watching Candid Camera and really enjoying that show.  This was definitely not Candid Camera in a normal sense, but being made by the same mind/genius, had certain elements that were similar...in a way.  It was very interesting to see the change in attitudes from the big issues of that era.  Really enjoyed this movie overall.

Funny, racy, and eye opening uncensored Candid Camera movie. Definitely worth a look at attitudes toward love and sex in the late 1960's and early 1970's. The second Candid Camera film, "Money Talks" was more for general audiences and rated PG. This originally got an X for nudity and sexual frankness before being re-rated R.

An interesting idea that was somewhat "shocking" at the time of its release but nowadays is rather blase. It was funny to hear the difference of opinion between the younger and older folks.

Interesting movie, especially considering when it was made. Full frontal male and female nudity but not portrayed in an erotic manner. Fun to watch the reactions that people have when confronted by a completely nude person in an everyday situation.
46 years ago and still great!

Really worth watching for several reasons. I like the very real slice of 1969 American society it depicts. Since the interviews are with real people and across an age and geographical spectrum it gives a great slice of the era.  Also some of the social experiments Alan Funt sets up are so real and useful. Especially the one with the 4 men in a room and then a 5th enters the area. Cool experiment on human nature.
Cute girls.....but so not funny

I remember watching Funt's Candid Camera in the 1960's and enjoyed the set-up situations a lot.
Here in the early days of the MPAA and loosening of restrictive sexual mores, it is an interesting time capsule.  I believe most of the interviews following the situations are honest and real and I found these to be a good window into the thoughts and responses of people of that period.
The only odd episode was the man who is in a pharmacy with the back of a female salesperson to the camera.  It doesn't seem to have a purpose.  Perhaps it was trimmed prior to or after initial release.
Very dated...not as good as the original tv show.
I LIKE it!

I saw this movie years ago and seeing a second time it lost the original shock value. It was a shocker when it was first release, but much has changed since then and while much is still funny, it does not shock like it did many years ago.

What memories! I first saw this movie in the theater. What a great date movie.
Funny, fun and very interesting ! There are so many sides to this topic, how to properly speak to a girl, as well as behave toward the female.

I felt a better job could have been done in casting the women who would be seen without their clothes on. Something about their appearance made it seem vulgar to me.  True, this is an old movie.  Yes Allen Funt was a real hoot on Candid Camera, but this movie reveals another side to him.  He was probably a real pervert just like a lot of Hollywood types.  I didn't like this movie so much, that I didn't even bother watching it to it's conclusion.  On the up side, it was basically free to watch, so the only thing wasted was my time as I grew increasingly skeptical and critical looking at it till I finally hit 'Stop.'

Bottom Line:  I think it's garbage and should be treated as such, left in the archives for historical purposes only in order to reference films in  bad-taste.
Humorous

Mildly amusing '70s hidden camera gags. It's pleasant enough to dip into at random points, if you really enjoy seeing random innocents being humiliated or abused, but I couldn't imagine sitting through it all at once. Oh - one more thing: the naked lady is one of the more appealing elements, but she doesn't appear nearly often enough.
Fun trip down memory lane. Soft porn at least. Interesting '60's commentary.
funny look back at how things were looked at back in the day. Allen Funt was great!

There were some very funny moments. However, warning to those who missed the '60's -- this movie is full of slang from the era that has since become out of use. Alan Funt was such a prankster.

I loved it; It was great fun. Alan Fundt - Candid Camera from the 1960 era. That was my era, Star Trek, Bonanza, Gilligan's Island, and Candid Camera were the TV shows to watch. There are dozens of shows out there that came from that simple idea, and it was to watch people in unusual situations and ask yourself "What would you do?".

It's Allen Funt without the restrictions of television and it's taboos.  He tries an experiment in an attempt to gauge the reactions of people to nudity, in several different social arenas.  The problem is that he is trying to practice amatuer psychology and fails.  Back in the day, this was probably worthwhile for its shock value.  Today, not so much.

It wasn't as good as I thought it would be,I think mainly for the year it was made. The title is kinda misleading,there wasn't enough nudity for me lol.

As a kid, I love the Candid Camera series.  Little did I know that Alan Funt did an adult version of Candid Camera.  It was interesting to see what the perceptions and reactions were to sex and nudity in Naked Lady.  Recommend for adults only viewing- no children.

Candid Camera in the nude. The movie had its funny moments. It was more about how people react to seeing complete strangers in buff. Alan Funt was a master at getting people to face situations that they never imagined they would get into and he was so good at it that he caught people on camera that swore it would never happen to them. This is was slightly funny but very interesting.

This film had potential, showing the reaction of passers-by to more risqu scenes than could be aired on the television series Candid Camera. However, the risqu situation was mostly the same: a naked woman in public. There was a couple of other bits but for the most part the candid bit was naked women. Then there was the talking: Alan Funt talking to people what pornography is, what prostitution is, why nudity is wrong, etc. It gets old quick and the music doesn't help. Any program which has a cheerful song about rape has issues.

when alan funt's money manager stole all his money, he produced this thing, in order to put so money back into his accounts. i had read about the looting of his accounts and thought it might be interesting but i didn't like it. i did like his candid camera show. the accountant killed himself before he when to trial.
not my kind of movie, no script just a bunch of people being film when hey saw a girl naked. tits just tits. if you just whant to see bubys ot's ok

This may have been considered shocking in its day but now it is neither that or even entertaining.  Watched this out of curiosity having grown up during the Candid Camera on TV era.  Although there were three or four skits with naked women and one with a male (total frontal nudity) the title is misleading since the movie was more about measuring people's reaction to watching these skits.  Since most of these people were older, the reactions were fairly predictable.  While the TV show was funny watching the reaction of individuals to created situations, this was neither funny nor entertaining.
I remember this movie of candid camera from many years ago. Yes, there is nudity but done in an unobjectionable fashion. Great studies in social psychology

It was shocking back then but so mild and tame compared to what is available today!  Great to see how attitudes have changed in over 40 years and that is what held my interest.  The "rape" segment was the most shocking thing to me considering how we look at it today....the movie made a total joke out of it and that would obviously come off really back today.  The objection to the black and white couple was another thing that would never work today...which is a good thing for sure!  I don't think people would sign the releases for their images to be in this movie- fascinating how times have changed.
saw it in college many years ago and thought it was great! still like it but from an older persons historical perspective. how times chance.
What a great slice of American life from 1970. Real people in real situations giving their unvarnished opinions and reactions to sex and the human body
It was hysterical and even shocking when it came out ... but very tame by today's standards.  Worth a look, if you're studying the sexual mores of the time.

No Sex but full nude. If you have no hangups about the human body you can show this to kids. It is a bit dated documentary on sex a nudism. Put together well, it was much better than I thought it was going to be.
Very dated movie, I remembered seeing it when it came out, too many things have changed, but still has some funny moments.
Reminds me of an incident which once occurred to me a long, long time ago which I recall very fondly.
I loved this when it came out at the theaters but now its seen its better day. the only reason to watch it now is to bring back the seventy

A great snapshot of American life in the earlier days of the Sexual Revolution.  Watch it for the clothes (really!) and listen to the viewpoints which sound very odd to modern ears.  The music is pretty catchy, too. being written by commercial jingle master Steve Karmen.  Finally, there are some really funny moments.
I long remember this movie from my tens and some how I'd like to see an up dated version of this movie and then compare the two

This is a great movie, if only to show sociologically how American society has changed.
I like the playfulness and innocence of this movie ... and to think this was an X rated
movie when it came out in 1970.
I was a kid in 1970 and never got to see this, and later would never to think to watch
it because I just thought it would be silly, but it is cute and endearing and very interesting.
I think Allen Funt had the right idea ... I so much would rather see real people exposing
something real about themselves than all the computer-animated, explosive, violent
and nasty movies we see these days.
I'm very happy I watched this for free on Amazon Prime ... thank you Amazon.

I remember when this movie first came out and I watched it for the first time.  I was surprised that the various actresses who appeared nude in the movie agreed to do it.  But I suppose back then, they didn't have any inhibitions about doing this movie and to them it was just another paycheck.  What I like is that what happened as a result of this movie is that Allen Funt decided to do more by doing what he called "Candid Candid Camera" stunts that incorporated what he did in the movie and made it for direct-to-video access.  Its too bad that Vestron Video(the company that originally produced the VHS copies of this movie) will not or cannot make DVD copies so that the general public can purchase them.  (I believe there are at least 6 volumes of the "Candid Candid Camera" series on VHS and Vestron Video should try and put them on DVD).
it was not great but funny most of the time. Quality of picture was not great but seeing it was filmed in 60's/70's was acceptable
This was great when I first saw it in the theaters years ago. I bought a VHS copy some years ago and player died so i ordered a DVD.

When i was young this title interested me to see but when i finally saw it on this dvd it was awful. Several naked women at the start then a long time in between before there is another one at the very end. When he did the candid candid cameras in the 1980s they were full of nude women situations. This movie here after i ran it i felt like tossing it into the trash because of lack of nudity.

Would you rather hear a lecture on sex from a stuffy professorial type or a nude statuesque blonde with a beehive hairdo?  Allen Funt, host and creator of TV's "Candid Camera", proves to be a genial tour guide that is America's minefield of the birds and bees.  There are any number of amusing stunts on hand here but there are two segments that prove indelible.  One concerns interviews with people about interracial relationships.  Another is interviews with teenagers about their sexual experiences.  I don't know what's sadder the kids' misconceptions or their parents' reactions to what their offspring are saying.  I was expecting a dated exercise but Funt's film is timeless because as much as things have changed so little hasn't.  This was originally slapped with the "X" rating but today it would be borderline "PG-13".  For you ladies out there it's not only female nudity on display.  Funt throws you a bone by including a segment involving a nude male artist's model.  Look quick for Richard Roundtree.

There's not much to say about the actual film. It's dated, and represents a time in society that has passed; something like this could not be done today. For this reason, it remains a curiosity. It's also not nearly as raunchy or explicit as it's reputation makes it to be. It does have frequent nudity, male and female, but it's not done salaciously - tasteful, if you will. It's almost done in an innocent way.

Now for the DVD - for the first time (in the US, anyway), it is presented in it's original aspect ratio, 1.85:1, and is 16x9 enhanced. The picture quality is quite stunning. I could not tell if this was a matted presentation, or if it opens up from the (assumed) panned-and-scanned VHS full-frame version, but the framing looks good here. The only extra is it's original theatrical trailer.
This movie was very poor quality and was not at all like my husband remembers it.  I was disappointed also.

I would like to know how to get the European version of this film on a DVD that will play
in the United States, rather than the "Bible Belt" version.  The most obvious omission in
the "Bible Belt" version is the woman in an office in Greenwich Village interviewing a gay
man.  The version we saw in college, which we were TOLD was the European version had a
really beautiful woman wearing nothing but red, white and blue body paint.  The Bible Belt
version has a different woman wearing shorts and a top with a small tattoo or painted area
on her back. The body paint scene was the most beautiful moment in the film, but is omitted
from the "Bible Belt" version, which I accidentally purchased from my satellite provider.
So, how do you get the good version?

FOR ADULTS ONLY! Originally given a "X" rating. Now Rated "R". Running Time: 85 mins. We all remember the Candid Camera tv series which has been shown on and off since 1960-2004. It was originally known as "Candid Microphone" in 1948-49, 1951-52. Very popular on television in the 1960's and 1970's. This show was about a hidden television camera being set up and a practical joke being played on unsuspected real people that walk in by random. For example, a man would walk in to a cafe and sit on the stool to order some soup. Just as he begins to sip the soup with a spoon, the seat begins to lower. Everyone knew who Alan Funt was, the host of "Candid Camera", so when they saw him come out and he says "Smile, Your on Candid Camera", they knew it was a practical joke. They would then see themselves on television at a later date. (This is not in the movie). They never let a light, simple joke go too far or too long. To end the farce, the person was always told they were on "Candid Camera" and shown where the camera was. This movie is "Candid Camera" for adults only as it contains female frontal nudity and male frontal nudity with frank conversations about sex. The first joke is played at random on people who stand at an elevator. Suddenly a naked woman comes out and stands to ask them a question. The shock on the people's faces is priceless. Another joke is played where Alan Funt is disguised and talks to a woman in a room. There is a painting of a nude male on an easel. Alan excuses himself and says he will be back in a moment. A naked man enters the room. It is the male model in the painting. He sits in his position. The woman sees everything. Will she look at him or look away out of politeness? Every woman has different manners. Their are many practical jokes here and over 100 people are surprised. The great thing about Alan Funt was he was a great host and good at conversation with people. Always a gentleman, but Right On! Another great segment is you will hear middle-aged and mature senior men and woman share their opinions about sex, a naked statue - should it have a fig leaf or not, and nudity and sex in movies, including this movie. Remember, this is 1969. Another joke is senior citizens see a couple kissing, however this is a black man kissing a white woman in public. Is it right or wrong? Is it shocking? The seniors will give you their opinion. Richard Roundtree ( before "Shaft") is the black man with the white girl. Filmed in Miami, Florida. Followed by: Money Talks (1972). Another adult version by Alan Funt titled "Candid Candid Camera" was broadcast on HBO and Playboy Channel in 1982-87. I don't think you could do "Candid Camera" today as the times are different and people are different. We live in a fast-paced world, some people have become less tolerant and people are in a hurry to get somewhere. Hidden cameras are everywhere now...and Alan Funt has left us. On September 5, 1999, Alan Funt passed away at the age of 84. He had become incapacitated after a stroke in 1993. His son, Peter Funt, hosted with his father in 1987. Peter continued "Candid Camera" on television in 1996 with tv specials for the next 8 years. After 56 years of surprising people, Candid Camera came to an end in 2004. Candid Camera is now online at its own official website and is also seen on GMC - Gospel Music Channel. Original Candid Camera: Candid Camera - The Best of the 1960s: Volume One Candid Camera: The Best of the 1960s: Vol. 2. The Best of Candid Camera: The Best of the 1970s, Vol. 1.Candid Camera - The Best of the 1970s: Volume Two. Candid Camera: The Best of the 1980s. Candid Camera: Greatest Moments (1987) Candid Camera: The Best of the 1990s. Candid Camera the Best of Today Volume One. Candid Camera the Best of Today Volume Two. Candid Camera: 5 Decades of Smiles. Smile...This Was Candid Camera (2010) Candid Camera's Inspirational Smiles (2010)

It is an interesting take on how America views nudity. The rest of the world is very open about nudity and sexuality.
  With America it is very much a guilty pleasure, something that should be hidden.
As it works out, American movies that portray movie violence i.e. shootings, death and torture as the norm and Sex and nudity as not normal have it backwards!
  This movie shows what is wrong in America, with some fun nudity in unusual places.
It is a breath of fresh air, the human body nude is natural! Bloody violence and death are not!!!
  Great movie!!!

I saw this when is came out in the 70's and it was funny and sexy.  I saw a copy in a video rental store in the 90's and watched it again.  Granted women today are in better shape but the situations are just as funny as they ever were.  Watching us rough, horny men back the truck up when we actually watch our fantasies unfold is just too funny.  A great study in human nature at it's truest.

This is waaay before the age of personal trainers.  Not only is their a small amount of bare skin, but the bare skin they show ain't worth seein'.  This  stuff got better in the 80s, when there was ample supply of attractive, and less inhibited women.

I had forgot about the old Allen Funts shows & I remember seeing this at one of the downtown theatres.
It was considered a very strong movie at that time. In todays world it would be considered quite tame.

When I saw this movie back in 1970 or so it was daring. Actual female breasts! Actual fake female orgasms! Uncensored sex talk! Watching it again all these years later all of the daring stuff is pretty tame by today's standards. Sure, there's a lot of Candid Camera funny stuff about catching people "being themselves", but the fascinating thing to me is how this movie reveals what our attitudes were about sex back in the early 70's. I was awed how people dressed differently, talked differently, and basically had a whole different attitude than we have today. Plus it seemed like everybody smoked back then. I was about 20 back then so the first time I saw the movie everything seemed normal, except the "daring" parts, of course. In my second viewing all these years later I look at it more as a glimpse back at a different time in our history. Younger people will probably this movie sucks. Older people will understand what I'm talking about.
great

I saw this movie many years ago and thought it was pretty hilarious,but now I find it pretty boring for the most part. There a few good scenes but they are too few and too far apart. There is too much talking and not enough action.

very old and dated

I remember this was released when I was a teenager and the MPAA ratings code was in it's infancy. It was rated X at that time. The content is basically on par with what you see nowadays as far as nudity. Being a curious teenage male with hormones running wild I wanted to get in to see it but couldn't. Watching it now 4 decades later, it brought back to mind how the movies of that era were going into uncharted waters with more permissive material. But all it is about is seeing naked bodies. Sex and nudity is just that: sex and nudity. A good engrossing well written and directed story and subject matter wins everytime. Allen Funt of the TV show Candid Camera, probably had this idea in his head for years. A hidden camera and staged naked actress captures very different responses from unsuspecting people. It was an interesting idea back then but the times now are quite different.
